Thanks for your letter of April 15 about
the placement service. I presume that being away you
did not receive my previous note expressing joy that
NAEB will shortly be in position to do a real place¬
ment job. You will recall that I have been the one most
eager to see you get going in this, for I feel that this
is going to be one of the very vital requirements for
the success of educational television, and I do hope
that you will have sufficient budget to do the scale of
job that should be required. Incidentally, it has
occurred to me that some means should be found for
giving in-service training, and up-grading to some
of the people who come along who have good experience
records of one sort or another but little or no actual
television experience.
Our own efforts in this regard have been
quite minor and incorporated in our regular budget.
We simply assigned one of our girls to pulling the
various letters, etc. we had received together, and
she devised a form which she circulated to past appli¬
cants to get a measurement of their present interest
and experience. It’s not an extensive file at all, and
certainly nothing such as there should be. She will
get it bundled up and off to you as soon as she can.
I was hopeful that Mr. Walker could get
down to Washington so he could see the problems we
confront (and Ralph, of course, too) and thus be in
better position to serve us. I presume that we shall
continue to get letters, people will continue to drop
in, etc. , and we shall have to have some way of tak¬
ing care of them, and assuring proper follow-through.
But all this can be worked out as we go along.
Cordially,
7 do
Robert R. Mullen
Executive Director
